item.title: Good week for publications!
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Our PNAS paper on Jesus and projection came out And our piece on anonymity, motivation, and accuracy was accepted into JESP with minor revisions

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Congrats, Yph to your new first-authored paper, one step closer to a PhD!
Love,
Abba

item.title: Piece on affective polarization accepted into POQ
item.dc:creator: ylelkes

item.title: ggplot and directlabels
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: i'm not a fan of legends in graphs. in my mind, lines that are labeled directly are easier to read. This is done easily with directlabels package by Toby Dylan Hocking. Just create a ggplot object and wrap it in the command directlabels(). I used it, for example, to label a plot of abortion preferences overtime by liberal-conservative self-placement. [sourcecode language="plain"] abortion <- na.omit(ddply(.data=data, .variables=.(year,ideology), .fun=summarise, wtd.mean=mean(x=abortion,na.rm=T,weights=vcf0009a))) library(directlabels) library(ggplot2) direct.label(ggplot(abortion, aes(x = year, y = wtd.mean, colour=ideology)) + geom_line() + theme_bw() + opts(axis.title.x = theme_text(size = 12, vjust = .25)) + ylab("Support for Abortion Rights") + opts(legend.position="")+ scale_x_continuous(limits=c(1972,2015),breaks=seq(from=1972,to=2008,by=6))+xlab("Year"),"last.points") [/sourcecode]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I enjoy what you guys are up too. This type of clever work and coverage! Keep up the excellent works guys I've added you guys to my personal blogroll. My homepage :: read what he said (Werner)

item.title: Political Psych piece on religiosity, conservatism, and political engagement is out
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Our article is officially published: Malka, A., Lelkes, Y., Srivastava, S., Cohen, A. B., & Miller, D. T. (2012). The association of religiosity and political conservatism: The role of political engagement. Political Psychology, 33, 275-299. There was a blurb about this a little while back at BPS Research Digest.

item.title: ggplot and indicating N by color
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: I don't know if it's an original idea or not. But for a paper I'm working on with Jon Krosnick, we plotted the number of times a respondent voted in the past 10 years by the their stated likelihood of voting in the upcoming election across a variety of different scales. We wanted to indicate the number of respondents that used each response option (on the x-axis.) One possibility would to use a rug plot, but there's already a lot going on in these graphs. What we came up with--and we may be reinventing the wheel--was to use a color gradient to indicate N, with darker colors meaning more people used that response option. The result looked something like this:

item.title: Ari Malka on religion and politics
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: My friend and frequent collaborator Ariel Malka, a professor of psychology at Yeshiva University, just wrote an op-ed at Fox News.com: Are religious Americans always conservative?

item.title: POQ Piece: Affect, not Ideology: A Social Identity Perspective on Polarization
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded:
Edits were sent for proofing to POQ. Hence, In Press.  

Abstract

The current debate over the extent of polarization among the American mass public focuses on the extent to which policy attitudes have moved. While “maximalists” claim that partisans’ views on policies have become more extreme over time (Abramowitz 2010), “minimalists” (Fiorina and Abrams 2009) respond that the majority of Americans remain centrist, and that what little centrifugal movement has occurred reflects sorting, i.e., the increased association between partisanship and ideology. We argue in favor of an alternative definition of polarization, based on the classic concept of social distance (Bogardus 1947). Using data from a variety of sources, we demonstrate that both Republicans and Democrats increasingly dislike, even loathe their opponents. We also find that partisan affect is only weakly founded in policy attitudes; thus movement in policy attitudes may not explain affective polarization. The more plausible account lies in the nature of political campaigns; exposure to messages attacking the out-group confirms partisans’ biased views of their opponents.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hey! This post could not be written any better! Reading through this post reminds me of my old room mate!
He always kept talking about this. I will forward this post to him. Fairly certain he will have a good read. Many thanks for sharing!

item.title: Affective Polarization published and in the news
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Here's the gated poq article: http://poq.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/09/15/poq.nfs038.full.pdf and some "international" coverage: http://www.slate.fr/monde/62445/republicain-democrate-couple-possible http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2012/09/you-hate-me-you-really-hate-me http://jezebel.com/5947176/republicans-and-democrats-are-less-tolerant-of-interparty-marriage http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/09/really-would-you-let-your-daughter-marry-a-democrat/262959/

item.title: Two super-useful recently-discovered R packages to covert regression models to latex
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Stargazer Texreg Both handle a wide range of models, although there are some differences. Stargazer can convert multinom, for example, both convert lmer.

item.title: Statex: extracts statistics from R objects right into latex.
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: https://github.com/SachaEpskamp/staTeX From the description: This package can be used to extract and print statistical results in a TeX format for easy inclusion in Sweave. Take a t-test. t1 <- t.test(dv~group,var.equal=T) Input it into sweave/knitr \Sexpr{st(t1)} Get this: t(334) =1.72, p < 0.01. not bad and works with a number of objects--lm, anova, chi-square.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: And the man falsely funeral home in houston texas claiming to be Kim Ledger spoke on the phone, so you maay want to absorb it a coujple of negative reviews, you may look into the Internet and start shopping around. Funeral homes can help funeral home in houston texas you make all necessary arrangements. And so we communicate that information to them. Using an online flower retailer is becoming common practice these days," he said.

item.title: Insert word count into sweave/knitr documents
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: useful trick found on stackexchange 1. install texcount and enable write18. 2. add this to your preamble: \newcommand\wordcount{ \immediate\write18{texcount -sub=section \jobname.tex | grep "Section" | sed -e 's/+.*//' | sed -n \thesection p > 'count.txt'} (\input{count.txt}words)} 3. Insert the following into your rnw file, changing myfile to the name of your rnw file: \makeatletter\@@input|"echo `texcount -1 myfile.tex`| cut -c1-4"\makeatother

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's nott myy first time to visit this web site, i am visiting this site dailly and obtain nice information from here daily.

item.title: Code and Data for the Social Sciences: A Practitioner's Guide
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Useful primer on keeping your code and data in order, written by UChicago's Gentzkow and Shapiro

item.title: Fading in survey questions to reduce satisficing
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Fading in questions seems to lead to better data quality as it slows people down. Preventing Satisﬁcing in Online Surveys: A “Kapcha” to Ensure Higher Quality Data

item.title: Piece on cultural and economic conservatism accepted in JPSP
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Malka, A., Soto, C., Inzlicht, M., Lelkes, Y. (Forthcoming) Do Needs for Security and Certainty Predict Cultural and Economic Conservatism? A Cross-National Analysis. \emph{Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.} Malka-Soto-Inzlicht-Lelkes-in press-JPSP-1-27-14

item.title: very accessible review on "matching methods for causal inference"
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Stuart, E. A. (2010). Matching methods for causal inference: A review and a look forward. Statistical science: a review journal of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, 25(1), 1.

item.title: SDU and Aarhus
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: Had a fun and interesting week visiting a couple great departments (SDU Political Science and Journalism and Aarhus Political Science Denmark). Thanks especially to Erik Albaek and Rune Slothuus for hosting me.

item.title: Text refs to bibtex
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: I wanted to import all the refs from an article into my bibtex library. This tool made it pretty easy: http://text2bib.economics.utoronto.ca/index.php/index/convert. I just copy-pasted the refs from the fulltext of the article I was reading. Removed quotation marks, and that was pretty much it.

item.title: When attempting to fit the irregular polygon of Nature into the square hole of Theory, all researchers face a strong temptation to lop off the messy corners
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded:
the crisis in the social sciences:
http://www.psmag.com/navigation/health-and-behavior/can-social-scientists-save-themselves-human-behavior-78858/

item.title: combining reshape and tables packages to make tables
item.dc:creator: ylelkes
item.content:encoded: TAL GALILI wrote a function that combines two useful packages so you can create a publication quality table with reshape.
